of the largest and research organisations in the world to jointly push the frontiers of how scientific research is produced and delivers benefits to society we advocate science and the scientific community to help build the european research area and shape the global scientific agenda with members from and countries and from all parts of europe we speak with truly european voice bringing together research funding and research performing organisations our members make significant contribution to european scientific research and are crucial stakeholders in european science and research policymaking want to join us and help us strengthen innovative european research science europe currently has an open vacancy for an administrative and personal assistant science europe would like to congratulate ursula von der leyen for her election president of the european

commission ec we also would like to confirm our full support to mariya gabriel new commissioner for innovation research culture education and youth following the approval of the new college of commissioners by the european parliament from all of us at science europe science europe held its general assembly in brussels today marc schiltz the outgoing president has been for second mandate he is joined by ingrid petersson director general of the swedish research council for sustainable formas and by rosa menéndez president of the spanish national research csic the new governing board gathers members from across the entire membership science europe joins organisations in call to to pledge ambitious budget vital our practical guide to the international alignment of research data management was officially release in january ten months

later the guide recommendations have found their way into number of organisational and in some cases even national open science data management policies science europe warmly welcomes the strong commitment from mariya gabriel for innovation and youth to support excellent research in europe research is essential for europe to address the societal challenges and lead the transition to sustainable and digital economy and society ahead of the trilogue negotiations the budget for science europe calls the council to agree to substantial budgetary increase for horizon outcomes of horizon provide key contribution to economic growth european competitiveness and in finding solutions to societal and global challenges so far much of the focus of the transition towards open access has been scholarly and scientific articles however significant number of disciplines notably but

not only within the social sciences the arts and the humanities produce and heavily use books this briefing paper identifies the key issues at stake in implementing policy of open access to academic books and outlines recommendations for different stakeholder groups to facilitate and accelerate such policy for horizon europe strategic plan science europe urges the european commission to support research and innovation at all technological and societal readiness levels and to adopt objectives that are not limited to short term impact europe should dare to explore unexplored paths and support riskier experimentation moreover science europe recommends to reinforce series of factors to increase the scientific economic and societal impacts of horizon europe do you have any questions about science europe science europe aisblrue science brusselsbce dictionnaire informations recueillies destinées

intégralité mediapart ordinateur mobile tablette choisissez formule abonnement accéder illimité mediapart rédaction documents intérêts nouvelle fenêtre application mobile poursuivant navigation mediapart acceptez utilisation cookies contribuant réalisation statistiques proposition contenus services ciblés sites letzter staff these aren milky way stars we re our way to kill some galaxies but long before that happens we re already eating little chunks of them that the conclusion of new pair of papers published dec and dec last year in the astrophysical journal researchers found few thousand strange young stars at the edge of our galaxy the milky way and concluded that these had formed from material bitten off of the large and small magellanic clouds pair of dwarf galaxies that the milky way will eventually devour the stars stood out in their distant corner

of the milky way because that region isn producing many new stars these days unlike at the livelier denser galactic center most of the available fuel in the far reaches has already been used up but analysis showed that these stars were relatively young related the weirdest galaxies in the universe this region is really really far away adrian research fellow at the flatiron center for computational astrophysics in new york city and lead author of the dec paper said in statement farther than any known young stars in the milky way which are typically in the disk so right away was like holy smokes what is this further analysis showed that the stars seem to be made of unusual ingredients given their segment of the galaxy the bands of

light that reached earth suggested that at least the brightest stars in the cluster had unusually low metal content indicating that the material that produced them came from outside the milky way the likeliest culprit according to the second paper the leading arm of the magellanic stream cloud of gas extending from the magellanic clouds toward the milky way that isn dense enough with gas to produce stars its own what likely happened the researchers concluded is that gas from the stream at some point passed through the milky way creating ram pressure type of shock wave the streaming gas collided with native milky way gas that ram pressure combined with the milky way gravity compressed some of the magellanic stream gas enough that it clumped together under its own

gravity once that happened some of the clumps of gas got dense enough to form stars leading to the unlikely presence of young stars in the region this finding is big deal the researchers said because it could help scientists figure out exactly where the magellanic stream is located in space most of the methods researchers use to figure out the distance between star galaxy and earth don work well for loose clouds of gas so researchers need landmarks to locate these objects based these newfound stars the researchers concluded that the stream is about from the milky way closer than expected if the magellanic stream is closer especially the leading arm closest to our galaxy then likely to be incorporated into the milky way sooner than the current model

predicts david nidever an assistant professor of physics at montana state university and of the dec paper said in the statement this new data will help astronomers build better models of the magellanic clouds and stream to figure out where the system will go in the future and how it moved in the past the researchers said and that important for understanding the future of the milky way eventually that gas will turn into new stars in the milky disk nidever said right now our galaxy is using up gas faster than being replenished this extra gas coming in will help us replenish that reservoir and make sure that our galaxy continues to thrive and form new stars originally published live science get breaking science news monster snakes and dinosaurs

aliens spooky particles and more live science is part of future us inc an international media group and leading digital publisher visit our corporate site us inc west street floor york we use cookies and other tracking technologies to improve your browsing experience our site show personalized content and targeted ads analyze site traffic and understand where our audiences come from to learn more read our cookie policy please also read our privacy notice and terms of use which became effective december by choosing accept you consent to our use of cookies and other tracking technologies filed under teenager he went to prison for selling ecstasy but now his mdma research is debunking the bad science that got him there for the better part of christopher chased columbia university neuroscientist

across the country it started in chicago then student at the university of sent carl hart the neuroscientist an email introducing himself hart responded and asked for cv but when sent one and didn hear back he borrowed his girlfriend drove to the windy city and nervously waited after talk hart gave to deliver the document personally they didn have much time to talk so months later appeared again this time at talk hart gave in washington dc again there wasn time to get into deep conversation they finally connected in st louis in after hart gave talk drug addiction caught between past marred by prison sentence for selling ecstasy and an unsteady future studying the drug that put him away was convinced that hart researcher whose work shows that

drug policies are often far more dangerous than drugs themselves was the only person who might help an break into scientific research when they did speak after months of false starts he was like you ve been following everywhere what do you want says that when started letting everything go letting go meant telling hart about growing up near milwaukee joining gang at age and becoming drug dealer did year in juvenile corrections for fighting and damaging property and just after turning he was charged with two felonies both involving very small amounts of ecstasy says that the first felony was for selling three ecstasy pills to an undercover cop and that the second involved being present when another dealer sold pills remembers the judge citing the dangers of ecstasy

he handed down harsh punishment for dealing offense two years confinement four years extended supervision and record that would follow him for the rest of his life spent months at prairie chien correctional institution got into fight and was transferred to supermax facility he got out couldn find job then went back to prison after being arrested for selling marijuana he spent another months bouncing between three different correctional facilities he took classes and decided to become drug counselor wanted to redeem myself he says going to research these drugs and going to warn people about the horrors of this drug that was going to be how paid back society today is phd student who studies mdma but his work veered in an unexpected direction working under hart in columbia

neuropsychopharmacology lab is one of small handful of researchers nationwide who administer pure mdma the chemical sold in impure forms ecstasy molly to human study subjects right now the laws that govern mdma are based controversial research and work is part of rapidly growing body of studies that directly contradicts it and perhaps the only scientist in the field who has experienced the impact of those laws from within the prison system he also creating pipeline to help other formerly incarcerated people transition into scientific research for the barriers are steep personally he fighting stigma record that still haunts him when applying for apartments and jobs more than decade after his release and the deep cultural gulf between the ivy league and where he grew up scientifically he pushing for

studies that assess drug risks well benefits and for research that better contextualizes both there pushback there pressure to succeed and there uncertainty that even if he does his record could prevent him from working in drug research once his phd is complete know that doing good work and doing work that can eventually set people free he says with that in mind able to keep doing this is measured in practice and appearance standing he often wears neat ensembles complemented by glasses and offset by diamond studs sparkling from each ear small tattoo of three diamonds remnant from his gang days curls down his neck from behind his right ear when he lectures the neurobiology of amphetamines to undergrads in columbia drug and behaviors class he speaks slowly and

precisely habit developed over years of watching cops journalists sometimes even other researchers mischaracterize what scientists know and don about drugs underneath this composure he angry that there need to set people free especially since many in the medical community opposed making mdma illegal in the first place like other drugs the legal history of the chemical better known mdma is driven more by fear and politics than science developed agent in mdma gained popularity in the and party drug and psychotherapy tool used in conjunction with traditional treatments though the drug was not approved by the food and drug administration some therapists incorporated it into their treatment regimens for patients struggling with ptsd depression phobias and relationship problems they credited mdma with inducing empathy hailing the drug penicillin for

the soul that changed in the during first lady nancy reagan just say no campaign sharp uptick of young users and unpublished research indicating that similar amphetamine called mda caused cognitive damage when injected in rats prompted the drug enforcement administration to call for an emergency ban of mdma in bolstered by separate research that showed cognitive and nervous system damage in animals given mdma at levels wildly above what humans would take the dea classified mdma schedule the punitively harshest category reserved for drugs like heroin that are deemed to have no medical uses and high potential for abuse and set series of public hearings to determine if the classification would become permanent dea officials were shocked when mental health professionals pushed back psychiatrists pharmacologists and biochemists presented evidence

and testimony mdma therapeutic benefits throughout hearings in but the dea overruled these objections and dismissed the administrative law judge recommendation to give the drug far lighter schedule iii classification aside from stint in the when the classification was challenged mdma has stayed schedule when went to court in mdma dominated headlines the federal government had launched nationwide campaign publicizing the dangers of club drugs supported by body of studies that detailed mdma neurotoxicity and linked it to conditions including depression memory issues sleep problems paranoia psychotic episodes and motor degeneration oprah showed terrified parents scans that purportedly showed holes the drug had bored into girl brain just weeks before court date journalists were going wild about study published in science which suggested that using mdma multiple times over several

hours could increase the risk of developing parkinson and other related diseases later in life two of the ten animals in that study died alan leshner former director of the national institute drug abuse likened ecstasy to playing russian roulette with your brain function while served his time drug laws became harsher some of the studies that inspired them were coming under fire the scans promoted by oprah were revealed to be images of changes in cerebral blood flow not holes less than one year into sentence the science paper and an additional study were both retracted because methamphetamine was accidentally used instead of mdma several scientists said that the retraction was part of broader pattern of research that mdma potential neurotoxic effects over the next several years many additional

early studies were criticized for using heavy doses far beyond what people typically take extrapolating findings from studies street ecstasy where the amount of mdma in each pill is unknown failing to provide adequate control groups and injecting the drug instead of administering it orally human users typically take it at the same time emerging research painted more nuanced picture of the drug effects the brain many studies offered evidence that mdma can potentially damage cells that produce serotonin chemical that associated with mood and temperature regulation with heavy users being particularly at risk while other studies only found small differences in cognitive performance between users and faith in the neurotoxins model just kind of eroded says charles grob psychiatry and biobehavioral sciences professor at the ucla school of medicine

grob has conducted mdma research and has written about the political history of the drug he adds that mdma does carry risks such the increased likelihood of high blood pressure reactions and episodes of an inherited condition called malignant hyperthermia but he also says that the emphasis mdma neurotoxicity was distraction away from further exploring genuine risks that users might incur wasn aware of the controversy around mdma research until he left prison he wouldn even know the seismic changes in how studies were conducted and interpreted until he began studying drugs himself upon release enrolled in technical college then still strapped to an ankle monitor transferred to the university of in he was allowed to take classes but was denied campus housing due to his record he was accepted

to the mcnair scholars program an initiative that helps minority students transition into doctoral studies programs mcnair scholars receive two things that changed life stipend which gave him financial freedom when he couldn find work and mentor under krista lisdahl neuropsychologist who researches the cognitive impact of adolescent drug use began digging into ecstasy connections to depression using data lisdahl lab had already collected people with history of ecstasy use he found that users showed more depressive symptoms compared to control groups and that users with specific variant of the gene which is associated with psychiatric conditions showed even greater levels of depressive symptoms than users without the variant to these results supported the common belief that ecstasy can impair users by causing severe depressive mood disruptions but his conclusions

changed after finding review paper written by carl hart hart performed an analysis of studies meth cognitive effects when looking at results from brain imaging studies and from cognitive tests that examined things like memory attention and function hart found that control groups often users did better few tests than longtime meth users those differences though real were still within what scientists considered normal range those tests scans suggesting that even after years of using meth people still had normal brain function in spite of these observations there seems to be propensity to interpret any cognitive brain difference clinically significant abnormality hart wrote looked at his own research and found the same problem ecstasy users with specific gene variant had more depressive symptoms than control groups but were still essentially

normal kept seeing hart name and learned that the columbia researcher wasn much different from him hart also sold marijuana teenager after crack appeared in the miami neighborhood where he grew up hart turned to drug research way to warn people about the dangers of drugs time and time again he found that risks existed but were frequently exaggerated drug sentences were far more likely to leave permanent marks when they connected in st louis was embarrassed by his record says hart knew of his mentor so knew that he was doing the work hart says my first impression was what shame that he embarrassed when he doing the best he can wanted to make sure did whatever could to make sure that he realized that his life wasn over

because of mistake applied to columbia and didn make it but was recommended for bridge program that prepares students to transition into phd programs the following winter he found himself huddled around broken space heater in filthy bronx apartment which was the only place he could find that didn require background check he couldn believe he had made it to columbia today all but lives in hart lab he has small remnants of his past like the tiny solitary confinement torture sign his desk but columbia is mostly new world few people there understand the helplessness of watching friends back home get locked up many of them instead have trained all their lives to attend an ivy league college and don understand how hard it was for to try to

catch up following hart lead is determined not to repeat mistakes of the past much of the last years of mdma research challenges the initial neurotoxicity reports of the and early while studies have consistently shown that mdma can potentially damage serotonin cells later studies have contested the links between mdma use and problems with memory and brain function one study found that mdma can alleviate some parkinson symptoms for people who are low in specific brain chemical called dopamine small mountain of emerging research suggests possibilities for positive uses in psychotherapy nonprofit research and advocacy group called maps is currently testing mdma ptsd treatment their work has progressed to phase three clinical trial which is generally the final phase of testing before drug treatment protocol gains fda approval even

the field improves there evidence that methodological concerns about existing research remain one review that looked at mdma studies some published late and found that definitions of heavy versus light users varied so much between studies that heavy users in one study would have been considered light users in another making it unacceptably easy for researchers to report significant findings where no relationship exists separate review by the same author noted that current and past mdma research is further limited by studies that gather data from participants who use street ecstasy which often contains little no mdma the review also found that statistical errors biases and methodological problems were so pervasive in the field that despite wealth of studies that point to mdma causing brain damage the available data can

only suggest an association rather than causal relationship between mdma use and neurocognitive deficits several mdma researchers interviewed for this story said that in general scientists now are far more deliberate about careful study design and methodologies but comprehensively understanding the effects of the drug requires testing it in humans and hart are part of small group of scientists who are focusing human ecology the amounts and circumstances under which users actually take drugs though hart sometimes collaborates with researchers who study drug effects in animals his team only studies human subjects which requires overcoming enormous regulatory and infrastructure hurdles including obtaining dea license and recruiting physicians and psychologists to ensure that research is conducted ethically and participants aren subjected to unreasonable harm under that umbrella of ecological relevance is

currently investigating two gaps in the scientific literature how amphetamines interact with other drugs since users often don stick to just one and the effects of repeated mdma dosing this work is slow and expensive experiments require finding participants who have no psychiatric disorders substance abuse issues physical conditions and who can pass an psychiatric interview and physical examination there hope that proving therapeutic use could lead to mdma being removed from schedule and potentially decriminalized that doesn help those who are currently struggling to move past drug convictions wants pardon hope catalyzed by wisconsin gov tony evers recent move to grant clemency to someone else who was convicted of selling ecstasy at age he also wants to help other formerly incarcerated people find the same pathways into science that

carl hart made possible in the formerly incarcerated research and science training first program an initiative that helps recently released enter science graduate programs and conduct research the roughly program covers basics like conducting literature review and applying to grad school it also provides participants with mentoring career development and stipend the challenges for first participants are enormous some spent decades in prison and are attempting to scale academia while transitioning into the mainstream facing employment barriers and adjusting to using basic technologies like cellphones and tablets still the program shows promise out of the five formerly incarcerated graduates in first inaugural class one joined the bridge program did while others are taking classes at columbia have obtained teaching assistant positions there how much the scientific community will embrace the

formerly incarcerated once classes are finished is question thinks about he moves through his phd for now he focused developing the skills to become an independent researcher and hoping that if he works hard enough science will take care of the rest just keep going he says just keep going thousands of years ago near what is today the british village of heslington man body started to decompose flesh and organs became mud hair turned to dust in the end bones remained and mysteriously small piece of his brain after months of patiently investigating the tissue proteins an international team of researchers finally has clues explaining this remarkable instance of preservation and it could help us better understand how healthy and unhealthy brains actually work the discovery of the heslington

brain one of the oldest specimens of human neural tissue ever to be uncovered in the uk left researchers with challenging puzzle to solve within moments of typical death brain tissue starts to decompose compared with other body parts this decay is especially rapid with various proteins going to work demolishing cellular infrastructure so when archaeologists looked inside skull pulled from an iron age dig site they were understandably shocked to see the withered remains of what looked like chunk of recognisable human brain according to carbon dating the man breathed his last breath somewhere between and bce most likely the result of fractured spine the kind you get after hanging exactly who he was why he died probably won ever be known sometime after his speculated execution though the

victim severed head was thrown into pit where it was encased in fine grain sediment soft tissues can often be preserved if they re desiccated frozen kept in an anaerobic acidic environment what especially strange in the case of the heslington skull is the lack of preservation of any other part of the body including hair for all appearances the firm material looks like caramelised chunk of human cerebral cortex only it percent smaller than an adult human brain the heslington brain dr axel petzold to work out what made the remaining organic material so special researchers took closer look at the nature of its proteins unlike most organs the brain needs to be well supported cellular level to operate maintaining connections within the complex weave of neurons and their

long bodies matrix of intermediate filaments ifs performs this task in living brains and it seems under the right circumstances they can retain some kind of integrity long after the cells have been reduced to molecular ashes we already know fair bit about these ifs based various pathological studies different cell types have their own types of filament and this specificity has attracted research for uncovering biomarkers for neurological diseases in the case of the heslington brain microscopy revealed weaves of ifs that resembled the long threads of axons making up living brain only shorter and narrower while antibody markers matching axon proteins confirmed they once housed the long neuron tails further analysis with specific antibody markers revealed disproportionate amount of neural structures belonging to helper cells such astrocytes with

fewer proteins marking out thinking grey matter tissue determining why these particular astrocyte ifs in particular didn follow the usual path of decay was never going to be simple there were no signs of the preserving tannins often seen in british bog bodies and while the specimen ph was towards the lower end the researchers weren confident they could use it to estimate the acidity of the body grave what more proteins that stick around at relatively warm temperatures tend to form stable structures and stable proteins don unfold easily unstable ones so over the course of year the researchers patiently measured the slow unwinding and breakdown of proteins in modern specimen of neural tissue and compared it with the decay within the heslington brain the results invited speculation over

chemical that blocks destructive enzymes called proteases in the months following death allowing the proteins to coalesce into stable aggregates that could persist at warmer temperatures combined the data suggest that the proteases of the ancient brain might have been inhibited by an unknown compound which had diffused from the outside of the brain to the deeper structures they write in their report what seems clear is that there was nothing particularly special about this poor iron age fellow brain rather something in the environment could have inhibited the chemical processes that would ordinarily break down the protein filaments responsible for supporting the brain white matter astrocytes at least long enough for it to clump into more robust form of course with only this incredibly unique sample to study it

hard to draw firm conclusions but even if the proposed unknown blocker turns out to be red herring research the way that ifs form stable aggregates could inform models explaining how destructive plaques form in our brain and with possible scraps of protein being found in fossils from time to time it would be good to have sound understanding of how they might unfold to deduce their original structures the strange brain from heslington still has few things to teach us yet this research was published in link down at time of publishing faculté sciences rabat blockchain technology is very popular and fashionable in this last decade this great innovation which emerged in meknès edition marrakech edition communauté ripam honorablement invitée rencontrer sol marocain assurance maladie obligatoire ensemble étudiants université

talent search regeneron sts recognizes and empowers our nation most promising young scientists who are developing ideas that could solve society most urgent challenges each year nearly students enter the regeneron sts submitting original research in critically important scientific fields of study unique among high school competitions the regeneron sts focuses identifying inspiring and engaging the most promising scientists among the nation high school seniors get program updates by including application dates for highlights from the regeneron sts finalists week was action packed meet the finalists take peek behind the scenes at public day and share the excitement of the awards gala in our highlights video for more detailed information view the winners press release june january january march march march the science talent search is arguably the most reputable

science competition for high schoolers in the entire world at the time majoring in engineering was daring choice my experience with the westinghouse science talent search gave the confidence to make this decision the legend was that these were the kids who would go to do amazing things make inventions win nobel prizes in regeneron made generous commitment to serve the exclusive partner for the science talent search through together we are helping the nation identify encourage and reward talented high school seniors in their pursuit of excellence in science math engineering and medicine science talent search alumni have gone to receive some of the world most esteemed academic honors including national medals of science five breakthrough prizes macarthur foundation fellowships two fields medals and nobel prizes they have founded

offerts lauréates varient totalisent participer devez citoyenne canadienne posséder statut résidente permanente résider québec an avoir accumulé échecs cours dernier trimestre fréquentation scolaire admissible attention prix réservés finissantes consultez guide mise candidature section prix chapeau filles admissible janvier mars concours chapeau filles volet excelle science mise jour janvier gouvernement québec the art of science communication is an online course that provides fundamental training in science communication focusing how to present science to nonexpert audience in formal setting such public lecture using video lectures background material virtual mentoring and discussions the course covers the important components of what makes for successful presentation including messaging generating interest and engaging with the audience the course is open to all scientists and stem professionals the course runs three times year the course is eight

weeks long weeks of learning and two weeks for preparation and delivery of final presentations for more information download the course syllabus read our paper in the science communication issue of the journal of microbiology biology education before the course begins each participant records short presentation scientific topic preferably the participant research topic the presentation should be appropriate for members of the lay public not audience this before video is used reference point for the weekly discussions and homework assignments and helps measure participant progress each week participants watch video lectures read background materials and review other resources weekly homework assignments help participants master the material there are mandatory weekly discussions video chat sessions platforms such skype google hangouts during which participants discuss that week content and assignments discussions are

led by members of the asbmb science outreach and communication committee and course graduates the final course project is another recorded presentation participants should plan to dedicate three to four hours to the course per week those who finish all the course requirements receive certificate of completion questions contact us at outreach asbmb org participants will be able to use the skills learned during the course in their professional lives postdoctoral laboratoire interdisciplinaire physique the asbmb training gave strength and confidence well certificate to apply for jobs outside of my academic comfort zone which ultimately brought one step closer to my dream making living out of my passion for communicating science to the world your grant applications learn from nsf nih and hhmi program directors how to write winning proposals

stored information and catalyzed reactions in primitive life earth meteorites contain number of organic compounds including components of proteins and nucleic acids among the constituent molecular classes of proteins and nucleic acids amino acids nucleobases phosphate and the presence of ribose and deoxyribose in space remains unclear here we provide evidence of extraterrestrial ribose and other bioessential sugars in primitive meteorites meteorites were carriers of prebiotic organic molecules to the early earth thus the detection of extraterrestrial sugars in meteorites implies the possibility that extraterrestrial sugars may have contributed to forming functional biopolymers like rna sugars are essential molecules for all terrestrial biota working in many biological processes ribose is particularly essential building block of rna which could have both stored information and catalyzed reactions in primitive life earth meteorites

contain number of organic compounds including key building blocks of life amino acids nucleobases and phosphate an amino acid has also been identified in cometary sample however the presence of extraterrestrial bioimportant sugars remains unclear we analyzed sugars in carbonaceous chondrites and show evidence of extraterrestrial ribose and other bioessential sugars in primitive meteorites the stable carbon isotope compositions vs vpdb of the detected sugars show that the sugars are of extraterrestrial origin we also conducted laboratory simulation experiment of potential sugar formation reaction in space the compositions of pentoses in meteorites and the composition of the products of the laboratory simulation suggest that meteoritic sugars were formed by processes the mineral compositions of these meteorites further suggest the formation of these sugars both before and after the accretion of

their parent asteroids meteorites were carriers of prebiotic organic molecules to the early earth thus the detection of extraterrestrial sugars in meteorites establishes the existence of natural geological routes to make and preserve them well raising the possibility that extraterrestrial sugars contributed to forming functional biopolymers like rna the early earth other primitive worlds sugars are indispensable molecules for life working along essential metabolic pathways and constituents of sugar phosphate backbone of genetic molecules dna and rna ribose is particularly essential building block of rna which could have both stored information and catalyzed reactions in primitive life earth thus the availability of abiotic sugars and their precursors the prebiotic earth has been investigated for many years numerous studies have been conducted meteoritic organic compounds particularly amino acids and nucleobases however

unlike these organic compounds an extraterrestrial origin for biological sugars in meteorites has not yet been proven in the researchers reported the detection of common biological sugars including arabinose xylose glucose and mannose fig in both carbonaceous and ordinary chondrites in comparable concentrations noted by the authors and the authors of subsequent review major problem was the possibility of terrestrial contamination of the detected aldoses since the cooper and coworkers carefully analyzed carbonaceous meteorites by gas spectrometry and detected the simplest ketose dihydroxyacetone in the murchison and murray meteorites with several sugar alcohols and sugar acids however dihydroxyacetone has lesser role in biology the phosphate is used in central metabolism but it has no known structural informational roles cooper and rios verified that several sugar acids and sugar alcohols are

extraterrestrial in origin having stable carbon isotope ratios that differ substantially from terrestrial sugar alcohols and sugar acids therefore to date no previous research has verified the presence of extraterrestrial aldoses other sugar compounds related to biological macromolecules in any astronomical sample structures of sugars detected in this study structures to and previous study structure shown in fischer projection from meteorites all sugars are shown for simplicity however chirality was not investigated in this study we detected all types of aldopentoses ribose arabinose xylose and lyxose in concentrations of to ppb from nwa and to ppb from the murchison meteorite fig table and appendix figs and several hexoses are also found in the nwa and the murchison meteorites conversely in nwa these sugars were below our detection limit for the

amount of sample analyzed ppb tetroses sugar acids and sugar alcohols containing carbon atoms ribitol and ribonic acid well and branched isomers of aldopentoses were below our detection limit in both meteorites ppb we also analyzed serpentine which had been baked in air at overnight an analytical blank and no pentoses were detected identification of pentoses in meteorites and reference standards total ion chromatogram and selected ion chromatograms of nwa extract mass fragment spectrum of ribose in nwa total ion chromatogram and selected ion chromatograms of the reference standard mixture mass fragment spectrum of ribose in the reference standard total ion chromatogram and selected ion chromatograms of the murchison extract total ion chromatogram and selected ion chromatograms of the reference standard mixture mass fragment spectrum of ribose in the murchison

mass fragment spectrum of ribose in the reference standard results of coordinated analysis of meteorites the values of ribose and xylose in nwa and ribose and arabinose in murchison showed significant enrichment to whereas xylose in murchison was lower figs and and see also appendix text the values of other sugars were not calculated because of low intensity poor peak separation the positive values are clearly distinct from biologically synthesized sugars for example pentoses and hexoses in algae higher plants and secondary producers all have negative values ranging between and fig we also analyzed the carbon isotope composition of pentoses extracted from soil sample that was collected in from the original murchison meteorite fall site in australia to indicate the values of likely contaminants the values of ribose arabinose and

xylose are even lower and all well outside the range of sugars we detected in meteorites the values of ribose and xylose in nwa and ribose and arabinose in murchison are comparable to those of sugar acids and sugar alcohols detected previously to in gra and murchison meteorites and those of acids in many carbonaceous chondrites which typically range from to this is very strong evidence that nwa and murchison contain extraterrestrial pentoses while enriched is usually an indicator of extraterrestrial origin slightly depleted does not always indicate terrestrial contamination for example many extraterrestrial carboxylic acids have negative values xylose in the murchison meteorite has distinct value from xylose in murchison soil although that is insufficiently distinct from biological sugars reported previously although no value could be determined for lyxose

this sugar may also be extraterrestrial due to its rarity in the biosphere furthermore the composition of sugars in the nwa and murchison meteorites are distinct from the compositions of sugars in extracellular carbohydrate polymers of desert soil algae showing the presence of ribose and lyxose in the meteorites and absence of these sugars in desert soil algae also support an extraterrestrial origin for these sugars the enantiomeric ratios of chiral molecules are sometimes used to evaluate the extent of biological contamination in abiotic synthesis products however this may not be useful for the evaluation of biological sugar contamination in meteorites since chiral compounds in murchison and other meteorites have been observed to have large excesses gas ratio mass spectrometry and chromatograms of derivatized extract with an internal standard and

the murchison extract single ion chromatogram of of the nwa extract single ion chromatogram of of the murchison extract signal ratio chromatogram of over of the nwa extract signal ratio chromatogram of over of the murchison extract stable carbon isotopic composition of sugars detected in this study with representative terrestrial and extraterrestrial organic compounds ref ref and ref the concentrations of detected extraterrestrial sugars are approximately orders of magnitude lower than those of amino acids and comparable to those of purines found in meteorites and those of sugar acids and sugar alcohols in the murchison meteorite the molecular structures of insoluble organic matter iom were analyzed with chemical shift attributed to aliphatic carbon is clearly more abundant than that from aromatic carbon in nwa whereas the aliphatic carbon signal was

comparable to the aromatic carbon signal in nwa fig the ratio of chemical shifts is indicator of the extent of chemical oxidation of meteorite organics associated with water the carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios of iom were analyzed with elemental ratio mass spectrometer the values of iom in these meteorites are comparable to those of typical carbonaceous meteorites table the nitrogen isotope composition air of the iom in the nwa meteorites showed significantly positive values and for nwa and nwa respectively which is characteristic of cr chondrites table alteration of minerals and insoluble organic matter profiles of the matrix in nwa the matrix is dominated by phyllosilicates saponite and serpentine based the presence of basal and prism reflections of these minerals profiles of the matrix in nwa indicating that anhydrous

silicates and feni metal kamacite are major phases electron image of part of type porphyritic olivine chondrule in nwa the chondrule mesostasis glass and kamacite are almost free from aqueous alteration products represents olivine nmr spectra of iom from nwa and nwa the aliphatic carbon signal of nwa iom is more abundant than the aromatic signal the aromatic carbon signal and aliphatic signal of nwa iom are comparable we also explored the minerals in both meteorites using synchrotron diffraction and scanning electron microscopy to assess the environments these meteorites experienced in their parent body asteroids observation of the nwa fragment showed that it contains large chondrules and metal grains with small amount of matrix chondrules and mineral fragments are not aqueously altered and are predominantly composed of olivine and pyroxene

grain boundaries of olivine in type porphyritic olivine chondrules are filled with unaltered mesostasis glass fig diffraction analysis of the matrix indicates that it is composed mainly of anhydrous silicates and kamacite and does not contain phyllosilicates fig and appendix fig small reflection at around is not serpentine but probably akaganeite iron hydroxide made by terrestrial weathering of kamacite if it was serpentine then prism reflections should have been detected was observed in the nwa matrix fig metals are partially altered to iron hydroxide by terrestrial weathering but magnetite is absent based the reported classification of cr chondrites the subtypes of nwa would be to indicating that this meteorite experienced very limited and aqueous processing in its parent body nwa also contains large chondrules grain boundaries of olivine in type

porphyritic olivine chondrules are filled with unaltered mesostasis glass the other hand matrix materials are dominated by phyllosilicates serpentine and saponite suggesting that aqueous alteration was pervasive in the matrix of nwa in contrast to nwa metals are partially altered to iron hydroxide by terrestrial weathering the presence of magnetite is not clear based the reported classification of cr chondrites the subtypes of nwa would be to the murchison meteorite is also and thus has experienced significant aqueous alteration the difference in the aqueous alteration history recorded in minerals is consistent with the recorded history of molecular structure of iom the formose reaction is thermally driven aqueous process producing number of sugars including ribose from aldehydes with alkaline catalysts reactions have been hypothesized to be related to iom formation reactions

are also capable of forming sugars in natural environments the fluid in the parent bodies of carbonaceous chondrites is thought to be alkaline and contains many cations including thus reaction would have been possible during aqueous processing in many of the parent asteroids of carbonaceous meteorites we also conducted laboratory experiment of the reaction to compare the product composition with the composition of sugars detected in this study fig the relative composition of aldopentoses in the product of the reaction is mostly consistent with the relative content of sugars detected in the nwa and murchison meteorites this indicates that the sugars in the meteorites detected in this study could be the products of reactions the concentrations of aldopentoses in reaction product the mineralogy and iom structure of nwa indicate that

aqueous alteration of this meteorite was very limited thus sugars in nwa could have been formed before accretion of the parent body during an early parent body aqueous alteration stage the formation of sugars before the accretion of meteorite parent bodies has been suggested in previous studies the iom structure and mineral compositions of nwa show higher extent of aqueous alteration in its parent body thus sugars in the nwa meteorite might have degraded in the parent body during aqueous alteration the murchison meteorite experienced much higher degree of aqueous alteration compared to the nwa however compositional differences in the mineralogy and in the fluid between these parent bodies may have resulted in different formation and preservation conditions for sugars for example many meteorites have high content relative to other

carbonaceous chondrites and can react with sugars and consume them the detection of ribose and other bioessential sugars in nwa and murchison that are isotopically distinct from terrestrial sugars provides clear evidence of an extraterrestrial origin for these sugars in primitive meteorites further this work provides evidence that prebiotic sugars could have been delivered to ancient environments the earth and possibly mars the detection of extraterrestrial sugars in meteorites establishes the existence of natural geological routes outside of the laboratory to make and preserve them the absence of deoxyribose well the presence of ribose in the natural geological routes further implies much more availability of ribose than deoxyribose the prebiotic earth this would be geological support of the rna world hypothesis we conducted coordinated analysis of carbonaceous meteorites which included

the identification of sugars stable carbon isotope analyses of the individual sugars stable carbon isotope and stable nitrogen isotope analyses of iom molecular structure analysis of iom and an evaluation of the mineral alteration appendix fig the carbonaceous meteorites investigated in this study were chondrites nwa and nwa and chondrite murchison meteorite typically chondrites contain larger amounts of soluble organic compounds such amino acids compared with other meteorite types the fragment of murchison meteorite investigated in this study was already analyzed for amino acids and it was established that this murchison meteorite fragment experienced minimal terrestrial contamination based mixture of the common biological amino acid alanine large fractions of the meteorites were used for sugar extraction because the sugar content was expected to be low the murchison meteorite has been

investigated for sugar and compounds in previous studies unlike previous studies we extracted sugars using hydrochloric acid and water from the meteorites to liberate all sugars from the mineral surfaces then this extract was purified and derivatized into aldonitrile acetates this derivatization has large advantages for the reliable identification and sensitive detection of sugars over traditional methods appendix text this derivatization has been used for the analysis of carbon isotope compositions of sugars in biological samples all data discussed in the paper have been made available to readers thanks benner and kim for helpful comments and their offer of branched pentose standards also thanks yoshida research and analytical center for giant molecules tohoku university for analysis part of this study was supported by tohoku university nanotechnology platform project this work
